On Thu, 10 Jun 2004 16:02:45 -0000, Philip Tucker <ptucker@...> wrote:
> You'd pretty much have to have interaction with humans for the
> fitness function, right?  

Yes, I think it would be interesting to have a website where people
could visit, which would load up two ANN-controlled faces.  The user
could be asked to observe each face for a set amount of time (e.g., 30
seconds), and choose the one that looked "more natural".  Success
would be contingent upon lots of traffic, but it would be an
interesting fitness function.

I'm reminded of Richard Dawkins in "The Blind Watchmaker", I think. 
He uses himself as the fitness function for evolving digital images of
creatures, like wasps.  The computer just initially created random
bitmap pictures, like 100x100.  He would pick the ones that "looked
more like a wasp", and they would then survive and mutate.  Eventually
he got bitmaps that looked like a whole lot like wasps.  (I could be
butchering the explanation...it's been a long time since I've read
that bit...)

But the concept of using human judgment as a fitness function is still
interesting and valid, I would think.

Derek
